Synergistic activity of single crystalline bismuth sulfide and sulfur doped graphene towards the electrocatalysis of tryptophan Subbiramaniyan Kubendhiran Natarajan Karikalan Shen-Ming Chen ⁎ Periyasamy Sundaresan Raj Karthik Electroanalysis and Bioelectrochemistry Lab, Department of Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology, National Taipei University of Technology, No.1, Section 3, Chung-Hsiao East Road, Taipei 106, Taiwan, ROC Electroanalysis and Bioelectrochemistry Lab Department of Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology National Taipei University of Technology No.1, Section 3, Chung-Hsiao East Road Taipei 106 Taiwan, ROC ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the present study, a single step and template free synthesis was proposed for the preparation of heterostructured single crystalline rod like bismuth sulfide/sulfur doped graphene (SGr-Bi2S3) nanocomposite. The structural properties and physical interactions of SGr-Bi2S3 were investigated by various physicochemical techniques which provide the knowledge about growth mechanism and orientation of reactive sites. These highly oriented edge reactive sites of SGr-Bi2S3 promoted the fascinating electrochemical performance towards the electrocatalysis of tryptophan (Trp). Trp is an essential biological compound it’s monitoring in human diet is quite important. Thereby, the SGr-Bi2S3 modified screen printed carbon electrode (SPCE) is applied to the determination of Trp. Trp is determined by differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) which revealed an acceptable sensitivity and lowest detection limit about 1.2 µA µM−1 cm−2 and 0.004 µM, respectively. These values are highly encouraged for the real time analysis of Trp in human blood (12–13 µg/mL). Moreover, it exhibited good selectivity over the range of interfering compounds (which present in blood co-exist with Trp). Therefore, this low-cost disposable SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE can applicable for the determination of Trp in biological samples. Keywords Electrocatalysis Synergistic effect Orientation of reactive sites Band gap Nucleation 1 Introduction Bismuth sulfide (Bi2S3) is an earliest photoconducting material, it was reported by T.W. Case in 1917. He conducted his studies on various metal chalcogenides and oxides, therein, only bismuthinite and lead antimony sulfide gave good results in photoconductivity [1]. Later, Goriunova et al. have studied the photoconductivity of Bi2S3 that revealed the band gap of 1.4 eV at room temperature, which is very suitable for photovoltaic conversion [2]. Therefore, Bi2S3 has recommended as a good material for photo responsive devices, liquid-junction solar cells, photodiodes and photovoltaics [3,4]. Moreover, it was applied in thermoelectric devices due to the Peltier effect and also applied in electrochemical sensors, supercapacitors, hydrogen storage devices and lithium ion batteries [5–8]. Owing to its versatile applications, Bi2S3 was prepared by various methodologies, including evaporation techniques, chemical depositions, hydrothermal or solvothermal and epitaxial growth [9–12]. Mostly, those methods are devoted to prepare the one dimensional (1D) Bi2S3, such as nanotubes, nanowires, nanosheets, nanorods and nanoribbons [13–16]. In many occasions, to improve the photocatalytic activity, Bi2S3 was combined with other semiconductor materials such as TiO2, Bi2WO6, BiOI, Fe3O4, BiVO4 and BiOCl [17,18]. The heterostructured Bi2S3/X provide an enhanced photocatalytic activity to the photovoltaics and dye degradation, because, this heterojunction provides good separation and transportation of charge carriers [18]. Therefore, the larger band gap materials can perform well in the visible light. Aforementioned heterojunctions are adequately documented in the previous literatures [15,17–19]. So far, Bi2S3 was introduced with aforesaid compounds to improve their photocatalytic activity. However, no reports were conducted for the improvement of Bi2S3 activity by introduce with some other low band gap materials than Bi2S3. Moreover, the photocatalysis of Bi2S3 has been comprehensively documented but only seldom reports were reported for the electrocatalysis. Therefore, we are planning to study the electrocatalytic properties of Bi2S3 with the sulfur doped graphene. In general, the single layer of pristine graphene have no band gap i.e., Eg = 0, however, the band gap have tunable with heteroatom dopant [20]. Some of the previous literatures are studied the band gap of pristine graphene and heteroatom doped graphene in the experimental and theoretical aspect [20]. These studies revealed that the heteroatom doped graphene showed an accessible band gap that could be tuned by varying the defects and doping percentage. Herein, we have concentrated on the facile one step synthesis of sulfur doped graphene with single crystalline Bi2S3 and studied their electrocatalytic behavior towards the biological important compound Trp. Generally, the Trp is naturally occurring indolic compound whose contribution is inevitable in biological systems. The US institute of medicine has recommended the dietary allowance of 5 mg/kg body weight/day of Trp for adults [21]. Insufficient supplementation of Trp leads to serotonin syndrome, in addition, the higher diet also leads to some potential side effects such as nausea, blurred vision, diarrhea and head ache [22]. Therefore, the detection of Trp received a great interest, hence, we examine the electrochemical detection of Trp by using Bi2S3/SGr. Interestingly, the Bi2S3/SGr heterostructure revealed a better activity when compared with previous reports. This activity is acquired from the interaction of Trp with the electronic structure of Bi2S3/SGr wherein the CB of Bi2S3/SGr is close to the HOMO of Trp which facilitates possible oxidation. Hitherto, many research groups were developed several electroactive catalysts for the determination of Trp. Those are exhibited the progressive improvements in their electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, we have compared the performance of our developed catalyst with recently reported literatures and the results were given in Table 1 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Bismuth nitrate, disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na2HPO4), sodium sulfide, sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH2PO4) and all the other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich chemical Co. All of the reagents were of analytical grade and were used as received. The SPCE (working area = 0.07 cm2) was purchased from Zensor R&D Co., LTD, Taiwan. 2.2 Methods The X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectra were taken from the Rigaku, MiniFlex II instrument and NT-MDT, NTEGRA SPECTRA instrument. The chemical composition and molecular interactions of SGr-Bi2S3 were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ULVAC-PHI 5000 Versa Prob X-ray photoelectron spectrometer). The obtained XPS peaks were fitted by using the XPSPEAK 4.1 software where the Lorentzian-Gaussian functions are fixed by 80:20. UV-DRS (JASCO V-770 spectrophotometer) and the high resolution transmission electron microscope studies (JEM-2100F (HR)). The fundamental electrocatalytic activity was performed by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and DPV using CHI 1205c and CHI 900 (CH Instruments, USA). A conventional three-electrode system has been used for the electrochemical studies where the catalyst modified SPCE is working electrode (0.07 cm2), platinum wire is an auxiliary electrode and sat. Ag/AgCl is used as a reference electrode (Eo (Ag/AgCl) ∼0.196 V). The phosphate buffer solutions (pH 3–11) were prepared by mixing the Na2HPO4 and NaH2PO4 with the suitable ratio and the pH was adjusted by HCl and NaOH. These PB solutions were used as electrolytes for the electrochemical experiments. 2.3 Preparation of SGr-Bi2S3 The simple one step, template free synthesis was portrayed in Scheme 1 . Initially, 13 mL of 10 mM Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was mixed with 2 mL of GO (25 mg/5mL) and then 150 mM of Na2S·5H2O (540.4 mg) was added slowly to the above solution under the continuous stirring. Finally, the stirred solution was transferred to the Teflon lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 h. The obtained black precipitate was centrifuged and washed well by using the double distilled water. The as-prepared SGr-Bi2S3 was dried in room temperature and stored in moisture free container. 2.4 Preparation of SGr-Bi2S3 modified electrode Before the electrode modification, the as-received SPCEs were gently washed with ethanol and water to remove the surface contaminates on the electrode. Then 7 µL of SGr-Bi2S3 dispersion (4 mg/mL) was drop casted on the SPCE and allow dry in hot air over at 50 °C. In same way, the SGr (2 mg/mL) and Bi2S3 (4 mg/mL) were drop casted on the SPCE. These modified electrodes were further applied to the electrochemical studies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of SGr-Bi2S3 The structural properties and interactions of SGr and Bi2S3 were investigated by variety of techniques i.e., XRD, Raman, XPS, HRTEM and SAED analysis. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Bi2S3 and SGr-Bi2S3 wherein all the observed diffraction peaks are highly indexed to the orthorhombic phase of Bi2S3. The obtained discrete peaks at 15.8°, 17.5°, 22.4°, 24.9°, 28.6°, 31.6°, 35.5°, 39.0°, 39.8°, 43.1°, 46.9°, 48.2° and 62.5° are corresponds to the (0 2 0), (1 2 0), (2 2 0), (1 3 0), (2 1 1), (0 4 0), (2 4 0), (0 4 1), (1 4 1), (2 5 0), (3 5 0), (0 6 0) and (1 7 1) planes, respectively. This observed patterns are closely matched with the standard data (JCPDS–17-0320), from this pattern, we have calculated the lattice constants i.e., a = 11.150, b = 11.306 Å and c = 3.992 Å [11]. Moreover, the obtained XRD patterns are exhibited the strong reflection peaks at (hkl) (l = 0) and weak peaks at (hkl) (l ≠ 0) [23]. This behavior insists that the as-prepared SGr-Bi2S3 have a preferential growth orientation in [0 0 1] direction (later this will be confirmed by HRTEM and SAED analysis). In addition, a small peak appeared at 24.98° in the SGr-Bi2S3 which corresponds to (0 0 2) plane of SGr (Fig. 1, inset) [24]. The similar XRD pattern was obtained for the as-prepared SGr, which evidences the presence of SGr in SGr-Bi2S3. Besides, the Raman spectra also confirmed the presence of SGr in SGr-Bi2S3, further it was utilized to investigate the defects and disorder of SGr-Bi2S3 (Fig. S1). The Raman spectrum of SGr-Bi2S3 was exhibited two broad bands at 1348 and 1576 cm−1, for the D and G band. As we know that, D band is attributed to the defects and disorder of sp2 carbon lattice, further, the G band is referred to the highly ordered arrangement of sp2 carbon [25]. This defect and disorder was mainly experienced from the oxygen functionalities in carbon lattice and also the hetero atom dopant. Moreover, the peaks appeared at 297.3, 423.4 and 962.1 cm−1 are corresponds to the Bi2S3 [26]. The XPS spectra were used to confirm the interaction of SGr and Bi2S3. Fig. 2 a shows the high resolution Bi 4f spectra which exhibited the strong peaks at 158.34 eV and 163.67 eV corresponds to the Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2, respectively. The observed peaks resulted that the existence of bismuth in SGr-Bi2S3 with the oxidation state of Bi3+. Moreover, the peaks at 161.02 eV and 162.21 eV attributed to the S 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [27]. This sulfur peak is corresponding to the S2− ions [27], additionally, it also contains the information of SGr but it cannot be deconvoluted due to the low intensity when compared with bismuth. Therefore, we confirmed the sulfur dopant by using the XPS of as-prepared SGr (Fig. S2). In addition, the peaks at 159.17 eV and 164.64 eV correspond to the BiOC bond [27]. This behavior confirmed the interaction of SGr with Bi2S3 through the oxygen. This will be further confirmed by the high resolution C1s and O1s spectra. Fig. 2b shows the high resolution C 1s spectra, which deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 284.3, 284.6 and 285.5 eV. The main peak at 284.3 eV is attributed to the highly ordered hexagonal sp2 carbon in the graphene. The peak at 284.6 eV is broadening with the signal of the mixtures of CS and CC (sp3) environments, this statement was agreed with the previous literatures [28]. The peak at 285.6 eV is corresponds to the COBi or CO bonding environment. There are no peaks at higher binding energies like 287–289 eV thus the OCO groups are not present in the SGr. Moreover, the high resolution O 1s core level spectrum was evaluated to further confirm the BiOC bond (Fig. 2c). The O 1s spectrum was deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 532.0 (O2 peak), 533.1 and 534.5 eV. The peak at 533.1 eV and 534.5 eV is attributed to the CO and BiO bonding environment, respectively. Therefore, from these comparative studies, we have confirmed that the SGr was highly interacted with the Bi2S3 through the COBi bond. Furthermore, this interaction was confirmed by the HRTEM and SAED pattern analysis. Fig. 2d shows the HRTEM image of SGr-Bi2S3, where the Bi2S3 is crystallized as a rod-like morphology on the SGr sheets. The length and diameters of the Bi2S3 nanorods were varied from 100 nm to 1.5 µm and 20 to 300 nm, respectively. It can be clearly seen that, the nucleation of Bi2S3 seeds are grown on SGr sheet which has a size about 50 nm (denoted in circles). In some places, the SGr was highly interacted with Bi2S3 (Fig. 2e) and gently covered as a layer, as shown in Fig. 2f. Fig. 2f shows the high magnification HRTEM image of Bi2S3 taken at the edge of nanorod wherein we can see the layers of SGr at the surface of Bi2S3. To investigate the orientation of SGr covered single crystalline SGr-Bi2S3 nanorods, the high magnification HRTEM and SAED pattern was evaluated for the same crystal edge by tilting the holder. Fig. 3 shows the HRTEM images and SAED pattern of SGr-Bi2S3 taken along the different zone axis of same crystal with the tilting process. Accompanied with XRD results, the SAED patterns and HRTEM images were indexed to the orthorhombic phase of Bi2S3 (JCPDS–17-0320). It can be seen that, the highly crystalline lattice fringes of SGr-Bi2S3 grown along the c-axis with ∼45 layers of Bi2S3 (Fig. 3a). Each layer contains the five sheets of sandwich type sulfide and bismuth in the alternative layer (see Fig. S3). Those layers are clearly shown in Fig. 3b as high magnified view. The distance between those obtained lattice fringes (layers of Bi2S3) is 0.793 nm (d spacing) which attributed to the (1 1 0) plane of the orthorhombic Bi2S3 [29]. Moreover, the interfacial angle between these two planes (1 1 0) and (0 0 1) is 90° which confirmed by SAED analysis (Fig. 3c). The SAED pattern was taken along the [1–10] zone axis which confirmed that SGr-Bi2S3 has the single crystalline nature and also preferentially grows in [0 0 1] direction, however this zone axis have no information about the SGr [29]. Therefore, the double tilt sample holder was randomly tilted to find out the lattices of SGr in the SGr-Bi2S3. Fig. 3d shows the same crystal edge with the different angle where the orientation of SGr-Bi2S3 layers are viewed by different zone axis. The d spacing of the layers are 0.251 nm which corresponds to the (2 4 0) plane (Fig. 3e). Here also, the lattice of SGr is not clearly seen however the SAED pattern identified the SGr with some ring patterns. This SAED pattern was taken along the [0 0 1] zone axis, where the spot patterns are again remained the single crystalline nature however the amorphous like rings are observed in this analysis (Fig. 3f). This amorphous like rings are corresponds to the reflection of SGr, may be this kind of amorphous morphology of SGr was experienced from the highly disordered low grain size of SGr. Further, the HRTEM image was taken at another angle (Fig. 3g), where the SGr is clearly seen in the high magnification view, there SGr was mentioned in arrow and drawn (Fig. 3h). The SAED pattern was taken along the [1 0 0] zone axis which also confirmed the presence of SGr by the amorphous ring pattern similar with [0 0 1] zone axis (Fig. 3i). Therefore, these studies are clearly confirmed the growth of single crystalline Bi2S3 nanorods on SGr and also revealed the interaction between Bi2S3 and SGr. From this knowledge, we have proposed the growth mechanism for Bi2S3 nanorods on the SGr sheets. 3.2 Growth mechanism of SGr-Bi2S3 The interaction of the SGr and Bi2S3 was predicted by various physicochemical techniques and the growth orientation and surface morphology of SGr-Bi2S3 was deeply probed by HRTEM and SAED analysis. In a simple experiment, first the bismuth nitrate was dissolved in deionized water wherein the bismuth oxynitrate was formed as a hydrolysis product [29]. Then it was converted to Bi2S3 when introduce with sodium sulfide. The synthesis process as follows: (1) Bi(NO3)3 + H2O → 2HNO3 + BiONO3 (2) 2BiONO3 + 3S2−+2H2O → Bi2S3 + 4OH−+2NO3 − (3) Bi2S3(nuclei) → Bi2S3(nanorod) (4) Bi(NO3)3 + H2O + GO → 2HNO3 + GO-BiONO3 (5) GO-BiONO3 + 3S2− + H2O → SGr-Bi2S3(nuclei) + 4OH− + 2NO3 − (6) SGr-Bi2S3(nuclei) → SGr-Bi2S3(nanorod) The steps (1)–(3) correspond to the Bi2S3 formation, where the bismuth oxynitrate was converted to Bi2S3 nuclei then it grows as Bi2S3 nanorod. In the case of SGr-Bi2S3, the similar process was happened however the additional GO was interacted with bismuth oxynitrate by the coordination of oxygen functionalities from GO. Before the hydrothermal process, this GO was successfully react with bismuth ions and formed as GO-BiONO3 complex. Then, the complex was simultaneously converted to SGr and Bi2S3 in a single step (5). This Bi2S3(nuclei) was successfully grown on the SGr sheets where the oxygen functionalities are richer in SGr. Then it will grow on the SGr and some places the SGr wraps the Bi2S3 by few layers. We have assumed that this SGr covered Bi2S3 revealed excellent electrochemical properties because of its efficient inter-molecular interactions. 3.3 Electrocatalysis of modified electrodes The ferricyanide ([Fe(CN)6]3/4−) redox probe was used to study the electrocatalytic properties of bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE. Fig. 4 a shows the CVs of bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE, which are recorded in 0.1 M KCl containing 5 mM [Fe(CN)6]3/4−. All modified electrodes showed the well-defined redox behavior for the one electron transfer of [Fe(CN)6]3/4− however the bare SPCE revealed comparatively low response for that reaction which exhibited the peak to peak separation (ΔEp) of 237 mV at 50 mV/s. This high value considered as quasi reversible reaction for the redox reaction of [Fe(CN)6]3/4− [25]. Among all, the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE revealed a better performance in terms of ΔEp and redox peak current when compared with the bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE and Bi2S3/SPCE. The ΔEp of Bi2S3/SPCE, SGr/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE are exhibited as 137, 133 and 113 mV respectively. All the modified electrodes are exhibited an acceptable electrochemical behavior in [Fe(CN)6]3/4− system, therefore, it is necessary to find out the effective heterogeneous rate constant (k o eff). The k o eff is the standard parameter for the evaluation of graphene based electrodes which are calculated from the ferricyanide or ruthenium hexamine system [30]. Here, we have calculated the k o eff for the bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE and the results were compared. The k o eff is calculated from the following equation [31]. (7) ψ = k o eff [ π Dn ν F / RT ] - 1 / 2 where Ψ is a kinetic parameter, F is the Faraday constant, R is the gas constant, T is the temperature (K), D is the diffusion coefficient of ferricyanide system, n is the number of electrons involved in the process. For the practical use, the kinetic parameter (Ψ) is tabulated as a function of ΔEp rather than a working curve. The tabulated Ψ is calculated for a one electron process (where the charge transfer coefficient, α = 0.5) at temperature (298 K). The kinetic parameter was deduced as a function of ΔEp by utilizing the Nicholson method. The empirical equation [32] (8) ψ = - 0.6288 + 0.0021 X / 1 - 0.017 X where X is ΔEp in mV used to determine the Ψ as a function of ΔEp, which are acquired from the experiments of cyclic voltammetry at the different scan rates. This CV experiment was performed in [Fe(CN)6]3/4− for scan rates from 10 to 200 mV/s, and the ΔEp is ranging from 85 to 169 mV for SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE. Later, the Ψ was plotted against the [πDnνF/RT]−1/2, from the slope we can calculate the k o eff [30]. The calculated k o eff values are 1.44 × 10−2, 5.75 × 10−2, 4.16 × 10−2 and 7.83 × 10−2 cm s−1 for the bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE and Bi2S3/SPCE, SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE. This study revealed that the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE has highest k o eff, this highest value supposed to produce the excellent electrochemical behavior for the analytes of interest. However, practically it seems to somewhat questionable for the analytes of interest with the orientation of active sites. Later, we have clearly documented the electrocatalytic activity of modified electrodes with the electroactive species. Furthermore, the electrochemical active surface area of modified and unmodified electrodes was estimated by using the Randles–Sevcik equation [25,33,34]. Thereby, the scan rate studies were performed in [Fe(CN)6]3/4− by varying the scan rates from 10 to 200 mV/s (Fig. 4b & Fig. S4–S6). The Randles– Sevcik equation as follows: (9) i p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 3 / 2 A D 1 / 2 C ν 1 / 2 where A is the electroactive area (cm2), D is the diffusion coefficient of [Fe(CN)6]3/4− (cm2 s-1), C is the concentration of the [Fe(CN)6]3/4− (mol cm-3), ip is the anodic or cathodic peak current (A), n is the number of transferred electrons and ν1/2 is the square root of scan rate (V s−1). For the calculations, we have chosen the slopes of Ipa versus ν1/2 (Fig. 4b, inset). The calculated electrochemical active surface areas of bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE and Bi2S3/SPCE, SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE are 0.059, 0.11, 0.078 and 0.2 cm2, respectively. Further, the existing electrochemical functionalities of bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE were evaluated by CV in 0.05 M phosphate buffer (PB) solution at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Fig. 4c displays the CVs of modified and unmodified electrodes, wherein the SGr/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE revealed a high background current (about 2 µA) that corresponds to the double layer capacitance. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 4c, the SGr/SPCE showed the similar response with SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE, but the response of Bi2S3/SPCE is very low. This behavior suggested that the Bi2S3 itself have no corresponding capacitance behavior therefore whole response of background enhancement is solely associated with the SGr. Generally, most of the carbon materials have micropores as a result the surface area would be increased. This micropores allows the electrolyte ions to accommodate inside that results the double layer formation. This double layer phenomenon exhibited more charge-discharge current this results high background current of SGr. Moreover, the SGr/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE showed the redox peak at 0.1 V vs Ag/AgCl which is associated with the hydroxyl (COH) functional group of SGr [35]. These modified electrodes were further applied to evaluate the electrocatalysis of Trp. Fig. 4d displays the CV curves of modified and unmodified SPCEs in the presence of 100 µM Trp which are recorded in 0.05 M PB solution at the scan rate of 50 mV/s. The rate of electro oxidation on Trp was varied at different modified and unmodified electrodes, it exhibited the onset of oxidation potential (Eonset) 0.736, 0.579, 0.724 and 0.566 V for the bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE, respectively. Moreover, the peak potential of the Trp oxidation was observed at Ep 0.865, 0.674, 0.860 and 0.686 V, respectively. Herein, the electrocatalytic activity of Trp was perplexing between those electrodes with validation. The activity was considered in terms of the activation potential (Ep-Eonset), where the bare SPCE, SGr/SPCE, Bi2S3/SPCE and SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE required 129, 95, 136 and 120 mV for attaining the peak current from the onset. These studies are documented the SGr/SPCE has the better electrocatalytic behavior for the oxidation of Trp in the aspect of oxidation potential however the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE exhibited the high electrocatalytic current. Therefore, we further investigated this electrocatalysis in the view of orientation of reactive sites. 3.4 Orientation of reactive sites and synergistic effect Generally, the electroactivity of most carbonaceous materials are laid on their edge plane and basal plane reactive sites [25,30–32]. Considering those planes, maximum of activity was acquired from the edge planes because of the accumulation of electrons. Usually, the electron densities of graphene are uniformly distributed at the basal planes and highly accumulated at the edge planes. Therefore, the accumulation of electrons at edge planes (or defects) is the reason for the better electrochemical performance. In our case, the similar phenomenon was happened for the SGr/SPCE however the pyrolytic carbon (bare SPCE) produces high oxidation peak current when compared with SGr (Fig. 4d). The reason is SPCE contains more defects thus it makes more edge active sites which facilitates high activity than SGr (because, SGr contains more highly oriented basal planes). On the other hand, Bi2S3 is a layered 2D material which also possesses the edge planes hence it produces the similar characteristics peak of bare SPCE. From this study, we have experienced the knowledge about edge planes activity, therefore, utilizing those information we have propose a possible orientation of SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE’s reactive site. As we stated above, the SGr was gently covers the rod of Bi2S3 by few layers, therefore we have given a model which portrays only one layer of SGr and Bi2S3. Scheme 2 shows the plausible orientation of SGr-Bi2S3, wherein the molecular orbitals of SGr and Bi2S3 was interacts together and revealed a typical electron flux. This flux was utilized by Trp at the surface of SGr-Bi2S3 and begin to the oxidative reaction. The predicted model has no bonding information however some electrostatic interactions are expected (see UV-DRS results in Fig. S7). The defects on SGr mostly considered as breaking the symmetry of sp2 carbon by the oxygen functionalities. These electrophilic oxygen (SGr-O*) welcomes the Trp by electrostatic interactions then it was oxidized by the Bi2S3. This statement was confirmed by the CV analysis of Trp oxidation by various cycles. Fig. 4e shows the CV responses of Trp oxidation at various cycles from 1 to 7. Initial run reveals no additional oxidation peaks rather than primary oxidation of Trp. The repetitive cycles revealed three oxidation and one reduction peaks for the corresponding oxidative and reductive products. Herein, the redox peak currents were increased when increasing the cycles from 2 to 7. This kind of redox peaks are not appeared in other modified electrode or unmodified electrodes (the third run of CV experiment was given in Fig. 4f, for all electrodes). Herein, SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE followed the EC mechanism for the oxidation of Trp. Initially, the Trp undergoes a complex 2e− transfer oxidation (in a single step or multi step) and then the protons were transferred by the same pathway. This irreversible oxidation reaction makes the Trp into 3-methyleneimine which immediately react with water and comes out from the electrode surface. Afterwards, it undergoes the redox reaction (at E = 0.1 V) while switching potential towards negative direction. This redox species (see Fig. 6 product (4)) is maybe occurred due to the thin layer effect of adsorption kinetics (discussed in next section) which leads to the further oxidations. Therefore, this study evinced the electrooxidation of Trp at SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE was acquired from the synergistic effect of SGr and Bi2S3. The actual interaction of SGr-Bi2S3 is unclear however the possibility is high with inter molecular interactions. 3.5 Mechanism of Trp oxidation at SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE The mechanism of Trp oxidation was demonstrated by Glenn Dryhurst et al. by the spectroscopic analysis with the electrochemical characterization [36]. Inspired by their results, we have investigated the reaction mechanism by using scan rate profile. Thereby, the CVs of Trp oxidation at SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE was recorded in similar experimental condition by varying scan rates from 20 to 200 mV/s (Fig. 5a). The experimental results of Trp oxidation was summarized as a mechanistic overview in Fig. 6. Initially, Trp is undergoing the irreversible oxidation with 2 e− transfer (primary peak O1 ) to produce the 3-methyleneimine (1) (Fig. 6). This reaction was preceded through the diffusion controlled process (the peak current of O1 is plotted against the square root of the scan rate, Fig. 5b). Therefore, CV of Trp doesn’t show any cathodic peak corresponds to the oxidation peak O1 , thus, the reaction product (1) must be extremely reactive with nucleophiles. Oikawa and Yonemitsu [37] have speculated that the product (1) is an intermediate species which involved in the Trp oxidation. The product (1) is the highly electrophilic reactive species which easily attack by any nucleophiles (for example H2O) in the reaction medium. Before Oikawa and Yonemitsu, no one report this species is an intermediate, hence, they have hypothesized that product (1) is similar with the initial oxidation product of tetrahydrocarbazoles. The nucleophiles such as Trp, exocyclic amino group and other possible groups can react with (1) that undergoes oligomeric or polymeric products. However, no significant electrochemical behavior was supported to the polymeric products. Therefore, we have considered the water is an only nucleophile would give the product indolenine (2) (some other diastereomers are also possible but not accounted here). This statement was evinced by the voltammograms of reduction peak R2 . Considerably, CVs of primary oxidation peak O1 resulted that the formation of many of reducible intermediates. However, we observed only one strong cathodic reduction peak R2 corresponding to the reduction of product (2) to 2,3,dihydro-3-hydroxytryptophan (4) via the 2 e−, 2H+ reduction pathway across the NC imine double bond. This reduction reaction was preceded through the adsorption controlled process (the peak currents were plotted against scan rate, Fig. 5c). However, the anodic peak O1 was corresponding to the diffusion reaction thus the product (1) is not the reducible product. Therefore, the product (1) must be reacts with H2O in the electrode–electrolyte interface (IHP-inner Helmholtz plane) where it adsorbed on the surface. Moreover, the primary reduction product (4) is quasi-reversibly oxidized into the oxidation product (2) via 2 e−, 2H+ (i.e., anodic peak O2 , Fig. 5a) transfer. In this case, the anodic reaction (peak O2 ) also proceed through the adsorption controlled process (the peak currents were plotted against scan rate, Fig. 5c). Therefore, the reducible product must be exists with the similar structure of product (2). From this study, we have concluded that the product (1) was undergoes hydrolysis to give (2). The product (2) also prone to the nucleophilic attack with H2O, it seems reasonable to form the product 2,3-dihydroxyindol (3). This product undergoes irreversible oxidation via 2 e−, 2H+ to give the product dioxindolylalanine (5). It is very hard to find the product (5) with the CV peaks, however, the oxidation peaks O3 and O4 is responsible for the product (5). The peaks O3 and O4 are revealed the similar characteristic response for the oxidation of (3), and also exhibited the adsorption kinetics for the oxidation reaction (Fig. 5d). This product undergoes the intra cyclization (6) with the interaction of amine with carbonyl group when it exposed to high pHs. Therefore, the pH study was investigated to analyze the intra cyclization products. Fig. 7 a shows the CV responses of Trp oxidation in various pHs ranging from 3 to 11. The peak potential of Trp oxidation (peak O1 ) was plotted against the pH and shown in inset of Fig. 7a. The plot shows the linear relationship with Ep vs pHs, however, the pH 7 is deviated from the linear fitted curve. The plot seems to be a pH dependent activity of Trp however the proton coupled electron transfer (PCET) is minimized by the factor of 0.0092 V (usually it is 0.0591 V but here it was 0.0499 V). Moreover, the plot of peak O2 and O3 follows the Nernstian behavior which revealed an almost closest slope value that suggested the PCET (Fig. 7b). This study concluded that the products (2), (3) and (6) undergo a nucleophilic attack before they participate in the electrochemical reactions. As said before, the nucleophile is to be a H2O in the case of (2) and (3). Hitherto, we have discussed the electrocatalysis of Trp on SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE with the mechanistic view. Furthermore, we have investigated the sensitivity and selectivity of the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE to the electrochemical determination of Trp. 3.6 Sensitivity and selectivity The sensitivity and selectivity of the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE was investigated by the DPV. This study has ensured the ability of developed electrocatalyst for the electrochemical sensor applications. Fig. 7c shows the DPV responses of SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE in the presence of Trp in the concentration ranging from 0.01 to 932 µM. The anodic peak currents of the products (1), (4) and (5) were increased with increasing the concentrations. The peak current of (1) was not linearly increased therefore the calibration function was analyzed by F-test. The detailed information of F-test analysis were reported by Danzer & Currie [59,60]. Moreover, our previous study also reported the F-test for the non-linear calibration function [33]. Briefly, three independent set of measurements (p) was carried out for the 11 standards (n, analyte concentrations) where all the replicated responses for the duplicated experiments were recorded and shown in Fig. 7c (inset). The standard deviations of analyte responses were inferred that this type of function called as a heteroscedastic case. From this data, the linearity was calculated by 0.01 to 120 µM and also we have calculated the sensitivity and lowest detection limit (LOD) of the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE are 1.2 µA µM−1 cm−2 and 0.004 µM towards the electrochemical detection of Trp. These analytical parameters can successfully apply to the determination of Trp in real time applications because the actual level of Trp concentration in blood is ranging from 12 to 13 µg/mL [61]. The obtained results were compared with previously reported electrocatalysts, which are published in 2016–2018 (Table 1). As shown in Table 1, the lowest detection limit of SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE was highly comparable and even very lower to the literatures [21,22,38–55]. However, the SnO2-Co3O4@rGO/IL/CPE [56], Pd−Cu@Cu2O/N-RGO/GCE [57] and Ce-ZnO/f-MWCNT/GCE [58] are manifested somewhat lower detection limits than SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE. In this case, the Pd−Cu@Cu2O/N-RGO/GCE and Ce-ZnO/f-MWCNT/GCE showed the similar limit of quantitation (LoQ) about 0.01 µM, but their LOD meets different value. And also, the SnO2-Co3O4@rGO/IL/CPE showed the LoQ about 0.02 µM which is higher than that of our LoQ however they showed the LOD about 0.0032 µM. Therefore, the evaluation of the performance over the LOD is perplexing between those materials, anyway the linear range of their materials manifested is much lower when compared with SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE. In addition, the synthesis procedures of these materials are highly meticulous and time consuming process. Not only these materials, many of the given materials also having the tedious synthesis protocol. Therefore, the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE provides an efficient platform to determine the Trp and also the reported analytical parameters are highly comparable with the state-of-the-art materials. The rationale behind this high performance was laid on the effective inter molecular interactions, high electron transfer rate, high electroactive surface area of SGr-Bi2S3. Moreover, the simple synthesis protocol, low production cost and easier fabrication will promote this SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE as a promising disposable sensor electrode for the determination of Trp. The selectivity of Trp on SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE was evaluated in similar compounds whose oxidation potentials near with Trp oxidation and some common ions by DPV. Fig. 7d shows the DPV curves of Trp oxidation with 5 fold excess of l-Cysteine (Cys), Histidine (His), Methionine (Met), Leucine (Leu), Serine (Ser), glucose (Glu), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and 10 fold excess of Co2+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Ni2+, Br−, NO3 − ions. The analyzed interference signals of aforementioned compounds were plotted against the response signal of Trp (where it kept as 100%). Fig. 7d (inset) shows the interference signal of tested compounds which exhibited less than ±5% interference signals corresponding to the response signal with Trp. Therefore, the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE can be applicable for the determination of Trp in biological samples. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated the facile protocol for the synthesis of SGr-Bi2S3 nanorods and applied in the electrochemical determination of Trp. The interaction of SGr and Bi2S3 was clearly investigated by various physicochemical techniques and predicted as a good model for the electrochemical reactions. Significantly, the XPS studies revealed that the SGr was highly interacted with Bi2S3 through oxygen and also the HRTEM and SAED analysis were confirmed the physical interactions of SGr and Bi2S3. This interaction promotes the electrochemical kinetics of SGr-Bi2S3 nanorods, which are evaluated by the ferricyanide redox probe. The SGr covered Bi2S3 nanorods were exhibited a remarkable electrocatalytic activity in ferricyanide and also to the oxidation of Trp. The oxidation of Trp proceeds through an EC mechanism as a result series of redox peaks was appeared. Those peaks were resolved by the scan rate studies with the aid of previous studies. Finally, the Trp was determined by SGr-Bi2S3 modified electrode which shows excellent sensitivity (1.2 µA µM−1 cm−2) and selectivity towards Trp with lowest detection limit of 0.004 µM. The actual concentration of Trp presents in the normal humans blood is 12–13 µg/mL. Thus, when considering the analytical parameters of SGr-Bi2S3, it can be applicable to the real time monitoring of Trp in human blood. In combination of good analytical performances of SGr-Bi2S3 with the disposable low cost SPCE promotes the SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE as a viable sensor electrode for the determination of Trp. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, a single step and template free synthesis was proposed for the preparation of heterostructured single crystalline rod like bismuth sulfide/sulfur doped graphene (SGr-Bi2S3) nanocomposite. The structural properties and physical interactions of SGr-Bi2S3 were investigated by various physicochemical techniques which provide the knowledge about growth mechanism and orientation of reactive sites. These highly oriented edge reactive sites of SGr-Bi2S3 promoted the fascinating electrochemical performance towards the electrocatalysis of tryptophan (Trp). Trp is an essential biological compound it’s monitoring in human diet is quite important. Thereby, the SGr-Bi2S3 modified screen printed carbon electrode (SPCE) is applied to the determination of Trp. Trp is determined by differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) which revealed an acceptable sensitivity and lowest detection limit about 1.2 µA µM−1 cm−2 and 0.004 µM, respectively. These values are highly encouraged for the real time analysis of Trp in human blood (12–13 µg/mL). Moreover, it exhibited good selectivity over the range of interfering compounds (which present in blood co-exist with Trp). Therefore, this low-cost disposable SGr-Bi2S3/SPCE can applicable for the determination of Trp in biological samples.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic activity of single crystalline bismuth sulfide and sulfur doped graphene towards the electrocatalysis of tryptophan
